text.title: Choose Recipes if You Have Sensory Issues
text.head: Choose Recipes if You Have Sensory Issues
text.p: If you have sensory issues and experience sensitivity to sounds , smells , flavors , or textures , mealtimes may be a challenge . If you ’re stuck in a rut trying to find meals , know that there are lots of ways to eat nutritious foods that you also can enjoy . Try new foods by keeping familiar elements in your recipes . Make small tweaks instead of major changes . Play with different textures until you find some that you enjoy . If you struggle greatly , consider seeing a professional for help .
text.head: Steps
Choosing Meals that Appeal to You

list.item:
Avoid recipes that rely on ingredients with a strong aroma . This might include cooked onions or garlic , strong spices , or other aromas you find displeasing . If a recipe calls for a strongly scented food , omit it or find a replacement that is more pleasing to you .
For example , substitute other vegetables ( such as broccoli or green pepper ) in place of onions .
Some other foods to avoid cooking because of their aroma might include ginger , cinnamon , or meat .

Choose preparation methods that are quiet . If noise bothers you , avoid recipes that require loud sounds , such as the blender or mixer . This might mean mixing ingredients by hand or cutting foods into small pieces on your own .
For example , if you want to make a smoothie but do n’t want to listen to the blender , make a simplified smoothie by adding a powdered protein mix to a liquid ( such as almond milk ) and shaking it in a covered cup .

Stick to your preferred food textures . You may prefer soft foods or crunchy foods . Whatever your preference , you can choose recipes that use those types of foods . For example , if you enjoy eating soft textures , choose recipes which cook the vegetables instead of eating them raw , or choose mashed potatoes over potato wedges . If you prefer crunchy textures , add nuts to your meals as a garnish .

Build off of preferred textures . Narrow your choices by searching recipes which include a food with a pleasant texture as a base . It might be too much to venture into trying full new recipes , so stick to the textures you prefer and add onto them .
For example , if you enjoy rice , look for rice dishes or meals that include rice as a major ingredient . This might mean making a stir fry , rice porridge , or a risotto .

Prepare foods with an undesirable texture in a new way . If you avoid foods due to their texture , think about using a new method to prepare or eat them . For example , you may dislike soggy cereal , so eat it dry or with yogurt instead of milk . Find creative ways to prepare foods so that you do n’t run into issues with texture .
If you dislike the texture of mushrooms , cut them into small pieces and put them into a dish with other foods you enjoy . If you do n’t enjoy mushrooms as the main course , use them in a smaller role .

text.head: Making Minor Adjustments to Meals

list.item:
Make small changes to foods . You do n’t have to get entirely out of your comfort zone to experience new things . Make a recipe you ’ve made before but tweak 1 or 2 things about it . For example , if you like to eat noodles , try ramen or udon noodles 1 night . If you enjoy rice , try brown rice 1 night . Making small changes to things you tend to like can help you discover new flavors and new recipes .
Do n’t make more than 1 or 2 changes per recipe . If you find a recipe in a cookbook , tailor it to your tastes with minimal changes to what you normally eat .

Sneak healthy foods into your favorite recipes . If you hate the texture of certain vegetables and struggle to eat enough , try cutting or blending them and putting them in foods you enjoy . Find ways to
‘ hide ’ healthy foods
that have a difficult texture for you so that you can still eat the foods you enjoy , just with some added nutrition .
For example , add vegetables to pasta sauce or micro-chopped carrots into a spread or dip .
Do n’t just stop at meals , try
adding healthy foods to desserts
as well !

Add condiments to iffy foods . Find which condiments you enjoy the most and add them to new or questionable foods . Knowing that you enjoy one food item can help you be open to enjoying another item .
If you ’re trying a new recipe as a guest at someone ’s house , consider bringing your own condiments such as mustard , mayonnaise , or ketchup if you are n’t sure they will be available .

Make mealtime predictable . One way to reduce stress around foods is to make mealtimes predictable and routine . Serve meals at the same time each day . Eat off of the same dinnerware each time . While these routines are simple , they can help ease stress by creating predictability and structure .

text.head: Getting Additional Help

list.item: Keep a record of which foods you enjoy . Have some ‘ go-to ’ foods that you know you enjoy and can eat regularly . People with sensory processing problems often enjoy bland foods such as pasta , rice , or potatoes . Try using these foods as a base for a recipe and try something new to go with it . That way , you ’ll eat something you know you enjoy but also have the opportunity to try something new .

Seek guidance from a dietitian . A registered dietitian can help you determine what foods to eat more or less of based on your needs . They can answer any questions you may have about diet , supplements , and nutrition . If you struggle to feel nourished after your meals , consult with a specialist to get a better idea of how to better balance your meals .
Ask your doctor to recommend a registered dietitian or look online at
http://www.eatright.org/find-an-expert
.

Make an appointment with an occupational therapist . If your sensory issues keep you from eating a balanced and nutritious diet , consider seeing an occupational therapist . Many people who struggle with foods tend to have other sensory issues that affect them outside of mealtime . An occupational therapist can help you accept more tastes and textures with your food selections and other sensitivities that may affect your day-to-day living .
Schedule an appointment with an occupational therapist by calling your insurance provider or a local health clinic near you . You can also speak with your physician for a referral or for a recommendation .
